metadata.title: Probabilistic Predictions. Embracing the uncertainty for better… | by Julian Wergieluk | Towards Data Science
metadata.description: In data science, the traditional approach to dealing with prediction error reminds me of the iceberg metaphor. Our models cannot predict the future perfectly, so we optimize them to push the…

all_paragraphs: In data science, the traditional approach to dealing with prediction error reminds me of the iceberg metaphor. Our models cannot predict the future perfectly, so we optimize them to push the prediction error down as far as we can go. Better models, hopefully, lead to smaller errors. But there is a certain lower bound no model will be able to beat: the Bayes error. The Bayes error is the manifestation of the randomness inherent to the underlying problem, which is often considerable.

Once we come close to this Bayes performance, we are tempted to declare victory and conclude our work. In doing so, we have dealt with the visible part of the iceberg. But, we can do so much better by diving in and building a model for the uncertainty part of the problem, the area of the iceberg we cannot see. Quantifying the uncertainty will allow us to amend the point predictions (= best guesses) with deviation estimates and, ultimately, will lead to better and more robust models we can trust.

In this article, I am going to talk about probabilistic predictions, which unify point prediction and uncertainty modeling in one consistent framework. Using probabilistic prediction models we can calculate best-guess predictions and derive the “safety buffers” that, together, result in well informed decisions and our piece of mind. Let’s dive in!

This might be a somewhat extreme example of a game of chances, but it’s an ideal playground to explain some fundamental concepts from the probability theory I am going to use in this article. In case you are not familiar with this “game”, I suggest you consult the following Wikipedia article.

The act of loading a gun with one round, spinning the cylinder and pulling the trigger is an example of a random experiment. The defining property of a random experiment is the fact that each repetition of such an experiment might lead to a different outcome, but the set of outcomes is known in advance.

In Russian roulette, there are two possible outcomes of the experiment: the gun fires or not. It is handy to assign a mathematical object Y to the outcome of a random experiment. Y is called a random element of the outcome set. (Sometimes people call Y a random variable.) This means that Y = ‘gun fired’, if that is the event we observed after pulling the trigger, and, otherwise, the value of Y is ‘gun didn’t fire’. If you are a programmer, you might think of Y as a function with no arguments that, if evaluated, returns the outcome of the experiment.

If we load a gun with just one round, spin the cylinder, and try to shoot, it probably won’t fire. More precisely, the probability of the gun firing is ⅙. Let’s celebrate this rare occasion: our intuition matches the mathematical definition of the thing exactly. The probability of an event is a number between 0 and 1. Zero means “it ain’t gonna happen”. We assign one to a surefire event. Numbers strictly between zero and one indicate various degrees of “likeliness”.

A probability distribution, often denoted by F, encodes the probabilities of the outcomes of a random experiment, or, equivalently, the probabilities of the possible values of a random element Y. So you might ask F, what is the probability that Y = “gun fires”. And F will give you the answer: F(Y = “gun fires”) = ⅙. Because F is so reliable in answering these questions, people sometimes call F the law of Y.

The business of mathematics is that of generalizing ideas and applying the results to new problems. It usually works as follows: now that we know almost everything about the classical and venerable Russian roulette, let’s go a bit further and define the game of Generalized Russian Roulette.

How about, instead of using just one round, we could use n rounds, and put those n rounds into a gun with an m-chamber cylinder. Obviously, we must require that n is between 0 and m, and m is a positive integer. (Usually m=6).
Given a gun with m=6 chambers, the probability distribution of Y is governed by the number of rounds X we put into the gun. What if X=2 (we use two rounds)? What would be F(Y = “gun fires”)?
In other words, different values of X yield different laws of Y.

The game of Generalized Russian Roulette is an example of a probabilistic classification problem. For different values of the input parameter X, we ask about the probability distribution of the outcome Y as a function of X. The set of outcomes is fixed and the same for all values of X, just the probabilities of those outcomes vary.

Usually, in a probabilistic classification problem, the probability distribution of Y is not given, and we are asked to guess or estimate it somehow. For example, given a picture of someone’s signature (X), we are asked to estimate the probability of that signature being genuine (Y=”genuine signature”) or a forgery (Y=”forged signature”).

For both classification problems just described, producing probabilities for different outcomes is much more useful than simply giving one most likely outcome as an answer, as typically classification algorithms would do. Imagine a business process set up to check signatures. An initial processing step might involve a probabilistic classification algorithm. If the algorithm is almost sure that a signature X is not a forgery, i.e. F(Y=”genuine signature”) > 0.95, we might mark it as genuine. For any value below 0.95, we employ further, more costly checks to investigate the validity of the signature.

The Russian Roulette example elucidates this point even more clearly. Any of the answers “gun will fire” / ”gun won’t fire” just doesn’t cut it. What we really want to know are those outcome probabilities.

I bought my current laptop on eBay a few years ago. It is a used Lenovo Thinkpad and the price I paid was considerably lower than the price of comparable new models. The market for used business laptops is large because a lot of companies regularly buy new hardware and get rid of the old machines. This market poses an interesting problem. Suppose we would like to buy a laptop with hardware parameters falling into a certain range. What is an optimal strategy for auction bidding that would result in a low purchase price?

We can frame this situation as a regression problem. Given a laptop’s hardware parameters X (possibly combined with the data about a laptop’s state and the reputation score of the seller), what can we say about the price Y of that machine? Y is a random quantity: it is driven not just by the feature values X, but also by random and unpredictable factors like user interest in a particular auction, possibly other ongoing auctions of similar models, the perceived value of the machine, time of day the auction ends, etc.

To come up with an optimal bidding strategy, we need to specify how urgently we need to purchase a laptop. If we need a new machine very urgently, then we should be willing to pay a high price and therefore bid above the best-guess price EY. If, on the other hand, we can just sit there and watch the market for weeks waiting for an “outlier” price, we should bid significantly below the point prediction price EY.

But what does it mean to bid significantly below the price EY? To answer this question, we need to know something about the predicted distribution of Y and reformulate our question in terms of probabilities for certain price ranges. For example, an outlier price could be a price that is lower than a price q0 with a probability of 1%. The threshold price q0 is a quantile of the distribution of Y, i.e., for a given probability p0=0.01, we expect to observe the prices lower than q only for 1 out of 100 sold laptops, on average. This statement is equivalent to the equation F(Y<q0) = 0.01, where F is the law of Y. Following the same line of thought, we could bid at a price q1 such that, with probability 0.9, the purchase price is lower than q1. This approach would quickly lead to a solution to the problem.

Let us emphasize that the quantiles q0 and q1 depend on the distribution F of Y (which depends on the feature vector X), as well as the confidence probability levels p0 = 0.01 and p1= 0.9. Also, we can view the problem of calculating the quantiles q0 and q1 as the problem of estimating one-sided prediction intervals (-∞, q0] and (-∞, q1].
All that is easy, once we have an estimate of the distribution F.

Many wholesale markets use auctions as a price finding mechanism, so the above discussion is relevant to many companies as well. For example, in the German wholesale electricity market, both buyers and sellers participate in an auction that results in a day-ahead price calculation. The electricity producers specify the price-volume pairs (p,v), and by doing so, set the amount of electricity v (in MW) they are willing to sell at a price that is not lower than p. Similarly, electricity consumers specify price-volume pairs (p,v) that indicate the amount v they are willing to buy at a price that is not higher than p. Using an auction mechanism to find one price that is used for all the settled transactions ensures that the largest possible amount of electricity is traded. All orders (p,v) that are compatible with that price are settled and the rest of the orders are discarded.

The Makridakis Competitions is a series of competitions organized by a forecasting researcher Spyros Makridakis to evaluate and drive the research on forecasting methods applicable to real-world problems. Recently, the fifth installment of the competition is in progress on the Kaggle platform, well-known among both data science researchers and enthusiasts.

The problem posed in it is that of predicting the number of units sold over 28 consecutive days in the future for a variety of products across the three product categories (food, household, and hobbies) in 10 selected Walmart stores. The training data consist of the time series of historical sales figures for all the product and store combinations over a few years.

An interesting aspect of this year’s competitions is that it comes in two variants: predicting the expected number of units sold (M5 Forecasting — Accuracy) and estimating 50%, 67%, 95% and 99% prediction intervals for the number of units sold (M5 Forecasting — Uncertainty).

This year’s problem seems very difficult not only because of the huge number of time-series involved (~30,000) but also because of the very “noisy” training data provided. Let’s have a look at an example time series from the training data set:

The buying behavior on the store level seems very erratic and difficult to predict. There are most likely some seasonal factors (weekly, yearly patterns, holidays) driving the intensity of the sales numbers. In most cases, the spikes of the sales numbers cannot be explained by the data provided. It makes sense: our lives are full of details that we do not share in public. Let’s say we and maybe 20 other people in our area recently watched a certain cooking show and decided to try baking Tarte au Citron. A retailer selling the necessary ingredients to prepare this Tarte doesn’t know anything about our plans, nor has any useful data to explain the sudden spike of demand for lemons.

From the perspective of a retailer, instead of trying to calculate the point predictions, it is much more useful to know, as precisely possible, the distributions of the future sales numbers. The above example illustrates how the expected number of sales is not at all helpful for handling unpredictable demand spikes.

As a retailer, we want to have enough on our shelves to handle these unexpected demand spikes and to prevent customers from having to search for the products they need elsewhere. On the other hand, every store has a limited presentation space, and some products are perishable and cannot be stored indefinitely. Also, the cost of storing perishable products is usually not negligible — think about those giant refrigerators found in supermarkets.

So, ultimately, the problem of maximizing customer satisfaction (and our revenue) is a probabilistic regression problem for the demand of each of the products we offer. We can assign probabilities to different demand scenarios (e.g. demand spike for lemons) and connect those scenarios to cost implications for the outcomes. Examples of costs could include: revenue decrease due to a not satisfying demand for a product, or the cost of losing a customer.

This is a typical setup of a decision-making problem under uncertainty. We look at different favorable or adverse events, and associate revenue or cost factors to them, and optimize a metric reflecting the business outcome.

In this article, we discussed gaining a more holistic understanding of data science problems through probabilistic predictions. We’ve shown that the submerged part of many real-world problems, the uncertainty, is as important to model as the visible Bayes performance element. Uncovering that uncertainty leads to more robust and trustworthy models, and opens a vital path to the development of strategic decision-making systems that can cope with a variety of future scenarios.
Many thanks to Sarah Khatry for reading drafts of this blog post and contributing countless improvement ideas and corrections.
Machine Learning Engineer & CEO of LOLML GmbH. I like mathematics, data science, meditation, and cooking.
